title: German submarine U-2344
text:
German submarine "U-2344" was a <a href="German%20Type%20XXIII%20submarine">Type XXIII</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Construction.
"U-2344" was ordered on 20 September 1943, and was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 4 September 1944 at <a href="Deutsche%20Werft">Deutsche Werft</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, as yard number 498. She was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 24 October 1944 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> under the command of "<a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a>" Hermann Ellerlage on 10 November of that year.
Design.
Like all <a href="Type%20XXIII%20submarine">Type XXIII</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a>s, "U-2344" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of (<a href="o/a">o/a</a>), a beam width of (o/a), and a draught depth of. The submarine was powered by one <a href="MWM%20GmbH">MWM</a> six-cylinder RS134S diesel engine providing , one <a href="AEG">AEG</a> GU4463-8 <a href="Motor-generator">double-acting electric motor</a> electric motor providing , and one <a href="Brown%2C%20Boveri%20%26amp%3B%20Cie">BBC</a> <a href="Silent%20running%20%28submarine%29">silent running</a> CCR188 electric motor providing .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate at for ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-2344" was fitted with two <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s in the bow. She could carry two preloaded <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es. The <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> was 14–18 men. This class of U-boat did not carry a deck gun.
History.
Like many other late war U-boats she arrived too late to turn the tide in favor of the Axis powers, despite her advanced design. "U-2344" never undertook an operational patrol, and was lost on 18 February 1945 after a collision with one of her sister ships, . She sank quickly in position , taking 11 of the 14 crew members aboard to the bottom with her. The wreck was subsequently raised for study in 1956, although she was not restored. Ultimately, the hull was <a href="Ship%20breaking">broken up</a> at <a href="Rostock">Rostock</a> in 1958.
